definition[0]: to prove that something is true or correct, or to make a document or agreement officially and legally acceptable
example[0]: The Supreme Court has validated the lower court’s interpretation of the law.
example[1]: Many scientists plan to wait until the results of the study are validated by future research.
definition[1]: to make someone feel that their ideas and feelings are respected and considered seriously
example[2]: Talking with people who think like you helps validate your feelings.
definition[2]: if a business validates a ticket from a parking garage, it puts a special mark on it, showing that it will pay the parking costs
definition[3]: to prove that something is true, correct, or acceptable
example[3]: The federal court overturned court rulings validating the company’s patent.
example[4]: Our data is validated to ensure reliability.
